Description: Season in which plants have active growth.

The base seeding rate (PLS)  represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Upper limit (Max) is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.

The base seeding rate (PLS) represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Lower limit (Min) represents least amount of seed that needs to be planted to achieve the low end of acceptable cover crop performance in a normal to good year (I.e. the cover crop is planted in a timely fashion and there is adequate rainfall and warmth).

C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.
Values Details: 1 = Lowest C:N Ratio, 5= Highest C:N Ratio

Description: Aerial seeding methods can be used for this crop.
Ending date when cover crop be planted into standing cash crop.
Starting date when cover crop be planted into standing cash crop.
Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Values Details: 1 = unlikely to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate

Description: Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.
Values Details: 1 = unlikely to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate

Description: Core description of cover crop for all zones.
Common name for categories of cover crops.
Plant common name as used when cover cropping.
Recommended cultivars, varieties, or subspecies of a plant that should be additionally specified for different regions.
Units/Details: list of strings separated by commas
Variable: cv, var, or ssp to specify

Description: Maximum depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch.
Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

Description: Minimum depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch.
Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

Description: Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A. Dry matter is highly dependent on planting and termination date and precipitation.
Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A. Dry matter is highly dependent on planting and termination date and precipitation.

Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.
Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows.
Values Details: 1= slow, 5 = fast. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.

Description: Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
Values Details:
1 = difficult to establish
5 = very easy to establish

Description: Speed at which the cover crop establishes once planted.
Values Details:
1 = slow to establish
5 = quick to establish

Description: Family common name.
Family scientific name.
Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.
Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size
General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).
Values Details: 1 =  worst for harvested forage, 5 = best for harvested forage

Description: Likelihood that conditions below 32 degrees F will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Values Details: 1 = requires a very significant freeze to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate in mild freeze

Description: Likelihood that freezing weather conditions will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.
Values Details: 1 = requires a very significant freeze to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate in mild freeze

Description: Cover crop can be broadcast seeded when ground is frozen.
Broadcast seeding with a tractor in a frozen field. Make sure the ground is frozen enough so tractors do not get stuck. Works best with heavier soils.

Broadcast seeding with a tractor in a frozen field. Make sure snow has melted enough for the seed to benefit from the thaw-freeze process that works the seed into the soil. Works best with heavier soils.
General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.
Values Details: 1 = worst for grazing, 5 = best for grazing

Description: Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.
Ability to tolerate heat relative to other species.
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: Hessian Fly-Free Date, after which wheat and other grasses can be planted to avoid Hessian fly and/or cereal rust.

Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.
Values Details: 1 = worst improvement, 5 = best improvement

Description:
Research Definition. Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Aggregate stability is a good indicator of soil health. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover of organic matter. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. 

Non-research definition: Soil aggregation is a key contributor to soil structure and tilth. It is an indicator of soil health, protects against erosion and improves soil structure, positively impacting soil water retention and drainage properties.
Values Details: 1 = worst aggregation, 5 = best aggregation

Description: Type of innoculant that needs to applied to legume seed to promote N fixation.
Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).
Values Details: 1 = shortest lasting residue, 5 = longest lasting residue

Description: Ability to tolerate poor fertility in general (an amalgamation of low pH soils and/or below-optimum soil tests for N, P, and/or K, sandy soil).
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: The maximum soil pH the cover crop can tolerate, in the top 12 inches of soil, as typically found in the Northeast.
Minimum temperature required for cover crop seed to germinate within 5 days.
The minimum soil pH the cover crop can tolerate, in the top 12 inches of soil, as typically found in the Northeast.
Likelihood that mowing (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that do not disturb the soil) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Values Details: 1 = unlikely to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate

Description: Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.
Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.
Rates legume cover crops for their ability to fix N by 50% bloom, which will vary by year and proximity to water/altitude.
Values Details: 1 = poorest N fixation, 5 = strongest N fixation

Description: Rates cover crop ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. To maximize N scavenging, plant the cover crop as soon as possible after main crop harvest or overseed/interseed into a standing cash crop. Highly-rated cover crops are useful in systems where manure is fall-applied to hold N in place over the winter.
Values Details: 1 = poorest N scavening, 5 = strongest N scavening

Description: Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Comments about specific diseases.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Comments about specific insects.
Comments about specific nematodes.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Additional taxonomic details, comments, and issues.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Who put this cover crop on this list?
Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't outcompete summer annual weeds, 5 = best for outcompeting summer annual weeds

Description: Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't penetrate plow pan, 5 = best for penetrating plow pan

Description: Indicates likelihood that the cover crop seed, once planted, will sit in the soil for an extended time then germinate at an inopportune moment (e.g., during cash crop growth). This is a long-term issue in which the "risk is in the cover crop seed bag".
Values Details: 1 = rarely has hard seed, 5 = hard seed is a frequent concern.

Description: Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.
Values Details: 1 = worst, 5 = best

Description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't prevent fall soil erosion, 5 = best at preventing fall soil erosion

Description: Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't prevent spring soil erosion, 5 = best at preventing spring soil erosion

Description: Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't reduce surface compaction, 5 = best at reducing surface compaction

Description: The Reliable Establishment period is an approximation. Relaible establishment is impacted by a number of environmental factors including soil temperature.
The Reliable Establishment period is an approximation. Relaible establishment is impacted by a number of environmental factors including soil temperature.
Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers summer annual weeds.
Values Details: 1 = residue doesn't suppress summer annual weeds, 5 = residue best at suppressing summer annual weeds

Description:
Likelihood that roller-crimping will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage. Termination is most successful at higher crop densities (3+ tons of dry matter per acre).


Roller crimping is usually used in tandem with chemical termination outside of organic systems.
Values Details: 1 = unlikely to terminate, 5 = likely to terminate

Description: Primary root structure: tap or fibrous.
Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).
Ability to tolerate high salinity relative to other species.
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: Full scientific name.

Variable: Second Temperature/Moisture Risk to Establishment End
Second Temperature/Moisture Risk to Establishment Start

Description: Relative cost of seed per pound.
Values Details: 1 = least expensive, 3 = most expensive.

Description: Average number of cover crop seeds in a pound of seed.
Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.
Values Details: 1 = intolerant, 5 = high tolerance

Description: Growth form or predominant shape of an individual plant.
Level of soil drainage needed for acceptable cover crop growth given regular rainfall.
Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.
Ability to establish and grow in soil with coarse, medium, and fine textured soils given regular rainfall.
Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.
Values Details: 1 = low support, 5 = high support

Description: Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.
Values Details: 1 = doesn't suppress Winter Annual Weeds, 5 = best at suppressing Winter Annual Weeds

Description: Common region-specific synonyms.
Units/Details: list of strings separated by commas

Description: Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Values Details:
1 = hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, 5 =  easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. 

The techniques are categorized as follows.
1-moldboard
2-rototill
3-chisel plow
4-heavy disk
5-light disk

Description: Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.
Values Details:
1 = hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, 5 =  easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. 

The techniques are categorized as follows.
1-moldboard
2-rototill
3-chisel plow
4-heavy disk
5-light disk

Description: Risk of previous cover crop volunteering in current cash crop due to management (i.e. the previous cover crop setting seed that becomes part of the soil weed seedbank). Impact depends on crop rotation (i.e. desirability of self-reseeding).
Values Details: 1= rarely volunteers, 5 = frequently volunteers

Description: Likelihood of cover crop survival over the winter.
Zone-specific description of cover crop, in addition to core description.
Should this cover crop be included in the dataset for this zone?
Whether the cover crop is commonly used in the zone or only beginning to gain adoption.
